feed.title: Jamanda Recipes

entry.title: Using Gen 3s Unused Flash Memory Section
entry.content:
A big issue I had with my original E-Reader events was space. I did not have enough of it!

The gen 3 games have a few defined spaces in the players save file for info obtained externally.

These are things like secret bases from other players, other players battle tower teams, and yes, information from the E-Reader.

The space defined for the Eon Ticket, specifically, is called RamScript. It’s 995 bytes in size.

For my first 6 events, I stored all my data in that location. This includes text, script commands, and assembly code. This is hardly ideal.

I played around with other storage solutions, but today I’m going to write about the best one I’ve found, and how to utilize it.

When a Gen 3 game saves, it transfers data from the GBAs RAM to the flash memory chip on the cartridge.

They also divided this flash memory chip into several sectors. Each sector is 4096 bytes, although some are lumped together.

Sectors 0-13 are for your save file.

Sectors 14-28 are for the backup of your save file

And sector 29 is for your hall of fame data.

In Ruby & Sapphire, 30 and 31 are entirely unused.

In Emerald, 31 is used for the battle record feature. But 30 is still unused. Or, it is, but only in international copies.

30 is used in Japanese Emerald & FRLG to store the custom trainer hill data from E-Cards.

This space is both unused & never written to normally by the game. This means it’s 4kb of space the player can’t accidently write to by using the battle tower!

The game has premade functions to read from and write to the flash chip, so we don’t have to do a lot of work to use it.

Let’s talk about writing, first.

I use TryWriteSector, & it has 2 arguments.

  1. Which flash memory section are we using. In our case, 0x1E, aka 30.
  2. Where is the data in RAM to flash?

Then, when called, it writes 4096 bytes from the location you input in as the argument are written to that flash sector.

When RSE connects to the E-Reader the entire e-card gets sent through the link cable into RSEs WRAM.

The game then looks for what’s called a “preload” script in the e-card. This is a section that runs the games scripting language commands, meant to check if the data is okay to send over.

The Eon Ticket, for example, checks if you already have an Eon Ticket in your bag.

Crucially, though, it does not have a size limit.

So, what I do is store tons of data in the preload script. One of those being a small assembly program that sets up then calls TryWriteSector.

Let’s take a look at what that looks like for me. This is all done using the Eon Ticket disassembly by hacky.

After DataStart, I set up the preloadscript.

DataStart:
	db IN_GAME_SCRIPT
	db 24,11 ; petalburg gym
	db 2   ; norman
	GBAPTR NormanScriptStart
	GBAPTR NormanScriptEnd

	db PRELOAD_SCRIPT
	GBAPTR PreloadScriptStart

	db END_OF_CHUNKS

PreloadScriptStart:
	setvirtualaddress PreloadScriptStart

PreloadScriptStart is where we’ll be working from, from now on. 

PreloadScriptStart:
	setvirtualaddress PreloadScriptStart

	callasm $02000045
    
	virtualloadpointer GoSeeYourFather
    
	setbyte 2
    
	dw $0000 
    
	end
    
	WriteFlashMemory

This is the start of my preload script. callasm $02000045 jumps the game to WriteFlashMemory. Crucially, it’s after “end”, so the thumb code never gets read as script commands.

WriteFlashMemory is the thumb assembly code I wrote to actually call TryWriteSector. It’s stored as machine code in an include file with the macros for the script commands.

I’ll note that in Emerald, if you copy this code, the callasm should be 0201C045 instead. Emeralds spot it loads the E-Reader into is slightly different.

Here’s what the actual code looks like:

WriteToUnusedFlashMemoryLocation:
movs r0, #0x1e    ;1E is the index of the unused flash memory block. 
ldr r1, [pc, #0xc];Loads WRAMLocation into r1.
ldr r2, [pc, #0xc];Loads TryWriteSector into r2
bx r2
.align
WRAMLocation:     ;This is where the data I want in the unused flash memory section is stored. 
0200005C          ;This is 0201C054 in Emerald
TryWriteSector:   ;this will change depending on game version and revision!
08125441

It’s a very simple bit of code since I’m just setting up the registers for a built-in function of the game.

After WriteFlashMemory, I have a bunch of code & data I want to store in the unused flash memory section. 

PreloadScriptStart:
	setvirtualaddress PreloadScriptStart

	callasm $02000045
    
	virtualloadpointer GoSeeYourFather
    
	setbyte 2
    
	dw $0000
    
	end
    
	WriteFlashMemory

	FillMapPattern   ;Everything on this line and after is what gets put into the save sector. 
    
	PatternStruct
    
	MOVEDOWN
    
	DEOGAMEORIGIN
    
	DEOMETLOC
    
	DEOEVENTLEGAL
    
	CLEFAIRY

	CLEFGAMEORIGIN
    
	CLEFMETLOC
    
	CLEFBALL
    
	CLEFAIRYSCRIPT    
    
	MOVEDEO
    
	DEOXYSSPRITE
    
	DEOXYSSPRITEPOINTER
    
	DEOXYSSPRITESETUPSCRIPT
    
	CLEFAIRYSCRIPT2

After this the usual ramscript information begins! This is what triggers when you talk to an NPC, and it’s labeled “NormanScript”, because it’s a hack of the Eon Ticket, and you receive that from Norman.

This script uses several “callasm” calls, which relies on info that is within the unused flash memory section.

That data is not loaded into RAM anywhere by default, so we have to run a function to pull it from the flash memory section!

In Ruby & Sapphire, since there is no Address Space Layout Randomization, I store the thumb code I need directly in RamScript near the top, like so:

NormanScriptStart:
	setvirtualaddress NormanScriptStart
    
	db $43              	;This checks if your party is bigger than 0

	compare LASTRESULT, 0   ;It's so I can store thumb code in static spot.

	virtualgotoif 2, Start  ;It should never fail.
    
	FAKEMAPHEADER
    
	READFLASH

Start:    

	callasm $02028DF9       ;This calls READFLASH
    
	lock

Let’s take a look at READFLASH. It works similarly to WriteFlashMemory, as we’re just setting up a different in-game function. It’s called DoReadFlashWholeSection in PokeRuby, & ReadFlashSector in PokeEmerald.

movs r0, #30 ;Index of the unused flash memory section
ldr r1, WRAMLocation ;where in ram I load the flash memory section to
ldr r3, DoReadFlashWholeSection ;actual function
bx r3
.align
WRAMLocation:
    .long 0x0201b201
DoReadFlashWholeSection:
    .long 0x08125bf9

I chose 0201b201 as it doesn’t seem to be a space the game uses, but I can’t guarantee!

But once this thumb runs, all my code & data is loaded to that space and my script can continue.

Obviously, in Emerald, this won’t work. What I do instead is store this code as writebytetoaddr commands. This, in a way, builds the thumb code live somewhere in Emeralds RAM that isn’t in ASLR space.

Each command does what it says on the tin-- it writes the byte specified to the address specified.

I tend to choose gEnemyParty for this, since it’s usually not in use when I’m talking to an NPC!

	writebytetoaddr $1E, $2024744
	writebytetoaddr $20, $2024745
	writebytetoaddr $01, $2024746
	writebytetoaddr $49, $2024747
	writebytetoaddr $01, $2024748
	writebytetoaddr $4B, $2024749
	writebytetoaddr $18, $202474A
	writebytetoaddr $47, $202474B
	writebytetoaddr $BC, $202474C
	writebytetoaddr $AB, $202474D
	writebytetoaddr $03, $202474E
	writebytetoaddr $02, $202474F
	writebytetoaddr $4D, $2024750
	writebytetoaddr $31, $2024751
	writebytetoaddr $15, $2024752
	writebytetoaddr $08, $2024753
    
	callasm $02024745 ;readflash

This is what that looks like!

It does eat 96 bytes into my payload, but I’m not really sure there’s a better way for Emerald.

Speaking of Emerald, I’ve actually taken to storing most of my events in this space, rather than ramscript. Since all the data at 0201b201 isn’t subject to ASLR, I can have the player get into battles & do other things without the typical worries I’d have.

My Celebi event, for example, only has code in RamScript to init the unused flash memory section. All the dialogue, script, etc, is stored in the unused flash section. 

NormanScriptStart:

    
	writebytetoaddr $1E, $2024744
	writebytetoaddr $20, $2024745
	writebytetoaddr $01, $2024746
	writebytetoaddr $49, $2024747
	writebytetoaddr $01, $2024748
	writebytetoaddr $4B, $2024749
	writebytetoaddr $18, $202474A
	writebytetoaddr $47, $202474B
	writebytetoaddr $BC, $202474C
	writebytetoaddr $AB, $202474D
	writebytetoaddr $03, $202474E
	writebytetoaddr $02, $202474F
	writebytetoaddr $4D, $2024750
	writebytetoaddr $31, $2024751
	writebytetoaddr $15, $2024752
	writebytetoaddr $08, $2024753
    
	callasm $02024745 ;readflash

	goto $0203abbc ;this is a jump command but in the scripting language for gen 3.

That’s RamScript for Celebi. Nothing else!

Here’s what’s in the Preload Script! It's the full source to my Celebi Event in Emerald. In Ruby & Sapphire, all of this would be within RamScript itself. 

PreloadScriptStart:
	setvirtualaddress PreloadScriptStart

	callasm $0201C045
    
	virtualloadpointer GoSeeYourFather
    
	setbyte 2
    
	dw $0000
    
	end

	WriteFlashMemory
    
CelebiScriptStart:
	setvirtualaddress CelebiScriptStart
    	db $00
     	dw $0000
        virtualmsgbox Poor
       	waitmsg
       	db $6E, $17, $8
        release

       	compare LASTRESULT, 0

       	virtualgotoif 1, Changemind    

       	virtualgotoif 5, CelebiEvent      	 
                     	 

           	db $00

           	TEMPCELEBI
           	STRUCTURETABLECOMPRESSED
           	LOADSTOREPARTYAMOUNT
           	CelebiRNGAlgo2
  	 
   


CelebiEvent:
       	db $43

       	compare LASTRESULT, 5

       	virtualgotoif 2, NoRoom

       	copyvar $800B, $800D

       	setwildbattle $F4, $30, $00

       	callasm $0203AC5D ;Colo RNG

       	special $13F

       	sound $13
   	 
       	waitstate

       	playmoncry $FB, $0

       	virtualmsgbox Celebi

       	waitmsg

        waitmoncry

       	waitkeypress

       	release

       	special $145
   	 
       	playsong $0166, $0

        waitmoncry
               	 
       	waitstate

       	db $43

       	comparevar LASTRESULT, $800B      	 
      	 
       	virtualgotoif 3, FlewAway

       	virtualgotoif 2, Catch




Catch:
        callasm $0203AD19
      	killscript



NoRoom:
	virtualmsgbox NoSpace
	waitmsg
	waitkeypress
	release
	end

Changemind:
	virtualmsgbox Change
	waitmsg
	waitkeypress
	release
	end


NoRoomToGive:
	virtualloadpointer PartyFull
	setbyte 3
	killscript   	 

FlewAway:
	db $97, $01
	db $97, $00
	virtualmsgbox Flew
	waitmsg
	waitkeypress
	release
	end

PartyFull:
	Text_EN "You need space in your party\n"
	Text_EN "to play this MYSTERY EVENT!@"
Poor:
	Text_EN "A Pokemon is rustling around\n"
	Text_EN "in this tree.\p"
	Text_EN "Would you like to investigate?@"
Change:
	Text_EN "Maybe another time.@"
Flew:
	Text_EN "The CELEBI flew away!@"

NoSpace:
	Text_EN "You need space in your party\n"
	Text_EN "to capture CELEBI!@"

Celebi:
	Text_EN "CELEBI: Biyoo!@"

GoSeeYourFather:
	Text_EN "A bright flash was seen in\n"
	Text_EN "PETALBURG WOODS!\p"
	Text_EN "Ever since, a rare Pokemon has\n"
	Text_EN "been seen healing thin trees.@"

I think, generally, using the Unused Flash Memory section is superior to storing data elsewhere in R/S/E, and if you’re going to do any Eon Ticket hack like I have, try to use this technique for storage instead!

Feel free to contact me if you’re trying to use this and have any questions. I can be reached @blisy on discord, @blisy.net on bsky, and imablisy@gmail.com via email!

-- im a blisy ._.

entry.title: Neapolitan Pizza
entry.content:
Ingredients

  • 110g sourdough starter.
  • .5 teaspoon active dry yeast if you don't have starter.
  • 1.25c lukewarm water
  • 1 tablespoon salt
  • 2.5c bread flour, plus extra for kneading.
  • Olive oil for greasing.

Procedure

  1. Mix water with Yeast or Starter & let bloom for 5-10 min.

  2. Mix flour & salt together in bowl.

  3. Add flour mixture to water mixture. Briefly mix until just combined into a shaggy dough.

  4. Lightly grease a bowl with olive oil. Put dough in, cover with kitchen towel and let rise until doubled in size.

    4a. Rising hack: Preheat oven to 200 degrees before you start this recipe, then turn it off once it's at 200. Put covered bowl in over. Dough should be doubled in 30 to an hour.

  5. After rise, cut in half (with knife or bench scraper, do not rip dough) and shape into balls.

  6. Lightly oil cutting board or sheet tray, place formed balls on top. Also very lightly oil top of balls, and cover in plastic wrap. Let rise in fridge for 4 hours minimum, and up to 3 days.

    6a. The longer you let the dough ferment in the fridge, the more flavor it will have. If you don't have sourdough starter, this is a great way to increase the flavor.

  7. Remove dough from fridge 1 to 2 hours before you are ready to bake it.

  8. Shape into Discs

  9. Bake on Pizza Stone at 550f.

entry.title: Baklava
entry.content:
Ingredients

  • 1 case of 16oz phyllo dough sheet (1 box has 2 rolls)
  • .75c melted butter
  • 1c simple syrup
  • 12oz pistachios, raw, unsalted
  • .333333333333333333333333333333333333333333333333333333333c powder sugar

Procedure

Make Simple Syrup

We make the syrup first so it cools down a little before adding it into the other recipe.

Ingredients

  • 4 cups white granulated sugar
  • 2 cups water
  • 2 tablespoons orange blossoms water
  • 1 tablespoon rose water
  • .5 small lemon

Simple Syrup Procedure

  1. Measure and add the sugar and water into a medium pot. Mix to dissolve the sugar very well.

  2. Bring the pot to medium heat. Right when the mixture starts to boil, time 5 minutes of boiling time. Then add in the orange and rose water as well as a squeeze of lemon juice into the pot.

  3. Continue to boil for 2 more minutes. Remove from heat and allow the syrup to cool completely before adding into a storage container or bottle.

Make Baklava

  1. Preheat Oven to 350f.

  2. Process the pistachios and powdered sugar in a food processor. Transfer to a bowl and set aside. You will split the amount into 2 portions, leaving some fir garnishing

  3. Unfold the phyllo sheets and smooth out to flatten. Cover with a damp towel, not wet, to prevent it from drying.

  4. Brush the base of a 9 x 14 inch pan with some ghee. Place one sheet of phyllo and brush again with ghee. Repeat to get a total of 15 sheets, brushing ghee in between each sheet. Add in half of the ground pistachio and spread evenly.

  5. Add in one sheet over the nuts and brush by dabbing only because it will move if you brush it normally. Add 9 more sheets, total 10 sheets, brushing in between each sheet. Press press down the surface very well with your palm to compress the nuts.

  6. Add the other half of the ground pistachio and top with 15 more sheets the same way you did the first layer. Before brushing the top with ghee for the last time, press down the surface really well again with your palm to compress the layers.

  7. Using a sharp knife with a pointed tip, cut the baklava into diamond shapes. Refer to my blog photos for step-by-step photo reference.

  8. Place the tray on the middle rack of your oven and bake for 40 minutes. At this point the edges and baklava should be lightly brown in color and you can turn on the top broiler for just 1-2 minutes watching it "very closely" until you get the golden color you prefer. Do not take your eyes off of it or else they will burn super fast.

  9. Remove from the oven and drizzle the simple syrup evenly all over the baklava. Use more or less to preference.

  10. Garnish with crushed pistachio

entry.title: Peach Iced Tea
entry.content:
Ingredients:

Simple Syrup

  • .75c sugar
  • .75c water
  • 16oz frozen peaches

Tea

  • 5 black tea bags
  • 8c water

Procedure:

  1. Bring sugar, water, and peaches to a boil in a small saucepan. Once the peaches have softened, use an emulsion blender to puree the syrup. Remove from heat and let steep for 25-30 minutes.

  2. In the meantime, brew your tea.

  3. Once brewed, remove tea bags and transfer to a pitcher. Refrigerate to cool.

  4. Once your simple syrup is finished, add to the pitcher. Don't strain, pulp will go through a metal sieve anyway.

Yield: 2 Quarts

entry.title: Whipped Coffee
entry.content:
Ingredients:

  • 2 tablespoons hot water
  • 2 tablespoons sugar (favorite type: turbinado sugar)
  • 2 tablespoons instant coffee powder (favorite brand Medaglia D’Oro)
  • 1 teaspoon Vanilla
  • Milk of choice, to serve
  • Ice, to serve

Procedure:

  1. Add the hot water, sugar, vanilla, and instant coffee to a large cup.

  2. Either hand whisk or use an electric mixer until the mixture is fluffy and light. Immersion blenders work the best.

  3. To serve, spoon a dollop over a cup of milk with ice in it and stir.

entry.title: Lemonade
entry.content:
Ingredients:

  • 1c sugar
  • 1c water
  • 9 lemons, more as needed
  • 6c water

Procedure:

  1. Make a simple syrup with the 1c sugar and 1c water.

  2. Juice 9 lemons into a gallon pitcher, strain out the seeds.

  3. Add the simple syrup and 6c of water. Taste and adjust with more water, sugar or lemons.

Variation: Strawberry Lemonade

Strawberry lemonade: puree 2lbs of strawberries, mix into lemonade, and strain out the pulp.

entry.title: Ginger Limeade
entry.content:
Ingredients:

  • 12Limes
  • 0.75c honey
  • 0.25lbs ginger root
  • 7c water

Procedure:

  1. Peel ginger and chop into smaller pieces. Use a food processor or blender to pulverize the ginger root.

    1a. Optional: add 1/2c of water to help blender the ginger.

  2. Boil 4c of water and add your pulverized ginger. Steep for about 10mins. Add your honey to the hot ginger tea to fully dissolve.

  3. Juice your limes into a gallon container. Using a strainer, pour your ginger, honey tea into the line juice and add your remaining 4c water.

Variation: Soda

In step 3, use 4c of seltzer for a natural ginger lime soda.

entry.title: Burger
entry.content:
Ingredients

  • 1lbs ground chuck
  • .5c Italian breadcrumbs
  • 1 large egg
  • 2 tablespoons Worcestershire sauce
  • 2 tablespoons milk
  • 1 teaspoon salt
  • 1 teaspoon garlic powder
  • 1 teaspoon onion powder
  • .5 teaspoon black pepper

Procedure

  1. Mix everything together in a bowl. Divide into 4 equal pieces and shape into patties.

  2. To store, wrap tightly in plastic wrap and put in freezer.

Yield: 4 Quarter Pound Burger Patties

entry.title: Parmesan Brussels Sprouts
entry.content:
Ingredients

  • 1.5lbs Brussels sprouts cleaned and halved
  • .125 teaspoon of salt
  • .5 teaspoon of pepper
  • 3 tablespoons olive oil
  • .5c shredded parmesan cheese
  • 1 teaspoon garlic powder
  • .5 teaspoon onion powder
  • .5 teaspoon Italian Seasonings (or whatever you like)

Procedure

  1. Preheat air fryer to 400F

  2. Toss all of the ingredients together in a bowl. And spread out on to the airfryer basket.

  3. Bake for about 12-15mins, until cooked through and have a crispy exterior. Toss once halfway through. Serve immediately.

Optional: Bake in a 400F oven for 15-20mins, place cut side of brussels face down.

Yield: 2 Servings of Brussies

entry.title: Red Sauce
entry.content:
Ingredients

  • 6 roma or 3 large heirloom tomatoes
  • 1 medium white onion
  • 6 cloves garlic (minimum)
  • .5 tube tomato paste(optional, but adds some more flavor).
  • 1 teaspoon of salt
  • .5 teaspoon of pepper
  • .5c shredded parmesan cheese
  • .5 teaspoon Italian Seasonings (Oregano, Parsely, whatever you have)
  • 2 teaspoons better than bouillon or 1 bouillon cube (any flavor)
  • Enough cooking olive oil to thinly coat bottom of pan

All ingredients are to taste. Feel free to play around with this one.

Procedure

  1. Thinly slice garlic (do not crush or mince, slicing preserves most flavor).

  2. Dice onion.

  3. Coat bottom of pan with olive oil, saute onion & garlic until aromatic on medium heat.

  4. While onion & garlic are cooking, cut tomato into chunks.

  5. When onion & garlic are ready (3 to 5 min), put tomato paste into pot & cook for another minute while mixing.

  6. Add chunked tomato into pot.

  7. Crush tomatoes with immersion blender until liquified.

  8. Add better than bouillon or bouillon. (Do not mix them with water as usual, the tomatoes have enough of that.)

  9. Cook sauce down on medium-low heat until desired consistency. Pizza sauce should be very thick, reduced by 60 to 70% of initial size.

  10. Once sauce is almost ready, add herbs.

Variation: San Marzano

Use 2 large cans of San Marzano hand crushed tomatoes, including their juice, instead of Tomato Sauce.

Yield: 4 Servings of Tomato Sauce.

entry.title: Pepcorn
entry.content:
Ingredients

  • .5c popcorn kernels (trust the process, this will make a lot of popcorn)
  • .5 teaspoon theater salt(use a spice grinder to turn salt into powder)
  • 3 tablespoons vegetable oil (neutral flavored oil, like vegetable)
  • Optional: Kernel Season’s, or homemade seasonings to garnish
  • Optional: Gochujang

Procedure

  1. Place the popcorn kernel, salt, and oil into a large, high walled pot, or use a wok. Mix to ensure the salt, seasoning, or Gochujang fully dissolves and the kernels are fully covered in oil. Cover with a lid or aluminum foil (poke vent holes in aluminum).

  2. Turn heat to high and let sit until the first pop. Start moving the pot to swirl and agitate the kernels, if using a lid, hold on to the lid! Continue motion until there are 4-5 seconds between pops. Turn off heat and let sit until all popping has stopped, about 30-60 seconds.

  3. Serve in a large bowl. Optional: top with Kernel’s Season’s, or homemade powders.

Yield: 2 Servings of Popcorn

entry.title: Tofu Schawarma
entry.content:
Ingredients

Tofu & Marinade

  • 1 Block of Tofu
  • .25c Soy Suace
  • 1 tablespoon maple syrup
  • 1 tablespoon olive oil
  • 1.5 tablespoons lemon juice(or half a lemon)
  • 1 teaspoon cumin
  • 1 teaspoon paprika
  • .5 teaspoon cinnamon

Bread & Fillings

  • Honey goat cheese
  • Veggies of your choice. We used Red Onion, Tomato, Cucumber, & Spinach
  • Tzatziki
  • Pita or Naan

Procedure

Optional: Homemade Tzatziki
  • 1c Greek Yogurt
  • 2 tabespoons olive oil
  • 2 teaspoon dried dill
  • .5 of a large cucumber
  • .5 teaspoon salt
  1. Shred cucumber in cheese grater
  2. Mix all ingredients together in Bowl.

  1. Mix all marinade ingredients except Tofu together.

  2. Press Tofu to drain water.

  3. Shred Tofu in cheese grater.

  4. Put Tofu in bowl, pour marinade on it. Let sit for at least 2 hours.

  5. Set Oven / Air Fryer to 400 F.

  6. Bake Tofu until crispy. At least 35 minutes, but check every 20 or so.

  7. Load up your Bread with tofu, veggies, cheese, & sauce & enjoy!
